sentences: He is widely regarded as being Canada's pre-eminent musician, from the 1920s through the 1950s.
He is widely regarded as being Canada's pre-eminent musician, from the 1920s through the 1950s.
Early life and education (1893–1914)
His father, who was a minister at St. Enoch's Presbyterian Church, bought an organ for a new house the family moved to in 1898.
His talents astonished the public and critics alike in 1904 when he performed in the "Festival of Lillies", which "firmly established him a prodigy".
Between 1908 and 1910, MacMillan held his first professional appointment as an organist and choirmaster in Toronto at Knox (Presbyterian) Church.
In 1910 he had his first official organ recital.
After that, he performed elsewhere in Toronto until 1914.
He earned the associateship and fellowship diplomas of the Royal College of Organists, and from 1911 to 1914 studied modern history at the University of Toronto, earning a BA.
Internment in Germany (1914–1919)
MacMillan traveled to Paris in the spring of 1914 and began to study piano privately with Thérèse Chaigneau.
Upon return to Canada in 1919, MacMillan was appointed organist and choirmaster in Toronto at the Timothy Eaton Memorial Church.
His career as a conductor truly began when he conducted a performance of Bach's St. Matthew Passion in the Timothy Eaton Memorial Church in 1923.
Later in his career (1948–1953), MacMillan introduced Canada to entirely new prospects of recording and broadcasting.
Influenced by the "war-time style and themes", the first performance of this piece was heard on February 8, 1925, by the Hart House String Quartet, and was conducted by MacMillan himself.
In 1927, he traveled alongside Marius Barbeau to the Nass River region of British Columbia to "hear, record and notate music of the Tsimshian People".
In addition, he composed Te Deum Landamus in E Minor (1936) and Song of Deliverance (1944), both choral works.
In addition, he composed Te Deum Landamus in E Minor (1936) and Song of Deliverance (1944), both choral works.
In 1953, he was asked to both compose and perform it at the University College in Toronto.
CBC Radio in the 1920s helped to heighten MacMillan's talent as a performer.
He was frequently asked to perform there, as well as in the United States, and at the 1935 Convention of the Royal College of Organists in Toronto.
He then established a conservatory choir in 1927, because he felt that the vocal students "needed experience in choral singing".
He also started the first opera classes at the conservatory in 1920, with performances of Hansel and Gretel, The Sorcerer, Dido and Aeneas and Hugh the Drover.

He improved the library, made improvements to the colleges' sight reading/ear tests, and prepared teaching materials which include "The Modern Piano Student" in 1931 and "On the Preparation of Ear Tests" in 1938.

He improved the library, made improvements to the colleges' sight reading/ear tests, and prepared teaching materials which include "The Modern Piano Student" in 1931 and "On the Preparation of Ear Tests" in 1938.
To enrich children's musical experience, he introduced a series called "Music for Young Folk" in 1942.

Alongside composing, conducting and performing, MacMillan additionally became recognized internationally as an adjudicator starting in 1924, when he participated as an adjudicator for the Ottawa Music Festival.
In 1937, he was the first Canadian to adjudicate at the National Eisteddfod of Wales; and he adjudicated at various festivals in Jamaica and the United States.
For his "services to music in Canada", MacMillan was knighted in 1935 by King George V on the recommendation of the Prime Minister of Canada, R. B. Bennett.
He became an honorary member of the Royal Academy of Music in 1938, and was also a recipient of the University of Alberta National Award in Music (1952).
He became an honorary member of the Royal Academy of Music in 1938, and was also a recipient of the University of Alberta National Award in Music (1952).
MacMillan also received the Canada Council Medal twice (1964 and 1973) for "outstanding achievements in the arts, humanities or social sciences".
The University of Toronto's Faculty of Music received a new facility in 1964, in which they named their new theatre "The MacMillan Theatre".
Ernest MacMillan died in Toronto in 1973.
The collection of Sir Ernest MacMillan's personal papers and music was established in the Music Archives, of the National Library of Canada, in Ottawa, Ontario, in 1984.
